title-group.article-title: Factors associated with timely initiation of antiretroviral therapy in two HIV clinics in Lilongwe, Malawi

article-meta.aff: ‡ International Training and Education Center for Health (I-TECH), Seattle, WA, USA

author-notes.corresp: Correspondence to: D C Johnson, Department of Epidemiology, School of Public Health, University of Alabama at Birmingham, 1665 University Blvd, Birmingham, AL 35294, USA Email: Frg1@uab.edu

abstract.p: The World Health Organization (WHO) estimates that only 30% of eligible, HIV-infected individuals start antiretroviral therapy (ART). This study seeks to explore the geographic and individual factors associated with starting ART on time. This retrospective study includes 15,734 HIV-positive adults initiating ART at two HIV clinics in Lilongwe, Malawi. The outcome was starting ART within two weeks of meeting ART eligibility as defined by the Malawi ART guidelines. Euclidean distance from patient neighbourhood to their clinic was calculated using Google Earth. Logistic regression models assessed factors influencing starting ART on time. Of 15,734 adults initiating ART, 8178 were from Lighthouse (LH) and 7556 were from Martin Preuss Center (MPC). Combined, 68.7% started treatment on time. Patients who were eligible for ART based on a CD4 cell count <250 cells/mm3 versus WHO stage were less likely to begin ART on time at both LH (odds ratio [OR] 0.16; 95% CI 0.13–0.19) and MPC (OR 0.24; 95% CI 0.21–0.28). Likelihood of starting on time decreased with each kilometer further from clinic location among LH patients (OR 0.97; 95% CI 0.94–0.99); distance was not significant at MPC. In conclusion, predictors differed by clinic. Distance to clinic and type of eligibility for ART significantly influence starting ART on time.

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Delaying antiretroviral therapy (ART) is associated with increased mortality, increased risk of tuberculosis (TB) and increased risk of AIDS-associated opportunistic infections. 1,2 However, a significant proportion of individuals living with HIV who become eligible to begin ART do not start within the recommended time frame. 3,4 Many factors contribute to delayed initiation of ART in sub-Saharan Africa. Individuals may need to weigh the benefits of starting and maintaining ART with the expected loss of income due to time spent away from work and family while seeking care. 5 Other economic factors such as food costs, school's fees and family obligations may also delay entry into HIV-related services. 6,7 Sociocultural factors, requirements to join a support group, partner notification or picking up medication from designated HIV clinics, might increase stigma and impede the timely start of ART. 8,9

In addition to the socioeconomic risk factors for poor health, an individual's place of residence also affects their wellbeing. 10 Rural residents, or individuals living further from city transportation hubs, may not have the time or money needed to travel to an HIV clinic, particularly if a clinic restricts when an individual can pick up their medication. 4 A study conducted in 4321 people in Uganda found that 44% of people who defaulted before starting ART noted transportation costs as the main reason for not starting treatment. 11 In South African clinics that do not charge for services, transportation costs frequently caused individuals to transfer to new treatment sites that were easier to access. 12 Other studies found that residing further than 10 km from an HIV clinic was a significant factor affecting individuals who were lost to follow-up before they initiated ART. 13 Ability to pay transportation costs may be associated with an individual's occupation and finances. In the Thyolo district of Malawi where the majority of employed individuals earn less than $4 USD per week, 14 the likelihood of ART initiation was four times more likely when transportation costs were halved. 15

Similar to other southern African countries, geographical and socioeconomic barriers to health care are known to delay ART initiation and negatively affect patient health in Malawi. 16 Currently, the HIV prevalence among adults (15–49 years) is 12% and over 930,000 individuals are living with HIV. Since 2004, the Malawian Ministry of Health provided free ART to eligible individuals living with HIV. 17 To date, over 300,000 HIV-infected individuals started ART. Early mortality within the programme due to advanced disease at ART initiation limits programme effectiveness. 18 Distance to clinics and access to ART may also influence whether individuals in Malawi start ART on time. 19 Given the serious potential consequences of late initiation, understanding factors associated with failure to begin ART on time in Malawi is critical for programme success.

Therefore, we examine both the individual and geographic factors associated with starting ART on time for newly diagnosed HIV-infected persons who initiate ART at one of two public ART clinics in Lilongwe, Malawi.

sec.title: Study setting
sec.p: Lighthouse Trust, a Malawian ART Center of Excellence, 20 works in close coordination with the Malawian Ministry of Health to operate two large integrated HIV testing, treatment and care clinics in Lilongwe, Malawi: Lighthouse (LH) clinic on the campus of Kamuzu Central Hospital and the Martin Preuss Center (MPC) at Bwaila Hospital, located next to the central transportation center for the city of Lilongwe. In 2002, Lighthouse was among the first public clinics to provide ART in Malawi. MPC opened in December 2006. Currently, the Lighthouse Trust is the largest public provider of free ART in the Central Region. Although the majority of ART sites in Malawi rely on paper-based records, LH clinics utilize a realtime electronic data system (EDS) to collect patient level information on ART patients since 2005 for LH and 2006 for MPC. During clinic registration for all pre-ART and ART services, patient location information is entered as free text into the EDS. Both clinics have nearly complete, electronic, patient-level data which enables effective monitoring and evaluation by LH data staff.

Malawi's 2008 National ART guidelines, used at LH, stipulate that individuals are not able to start ART until they have either a WHO staging of 3 or 4, or until they have a CD4 cell count of less than 250 cells/mm3. 21 If an individual is staged as WHO 3 or 4, then a CD4 cell count test may be done, but is not required for ART eligibility. Pre-ART patients, HIV-positive individuals who have not started ART, are reviewed every two months to provide co-trimoxazole therapy and to evaluate them for any potential stage 3 or 4 defining conditions. Pre-ART patients may seek care between visits if they are sick. CD4 counts are collected every six months to assess ART eligibility. Test results from a CD4 blood draw are typically available two weeks after the blood draw, and patients are asked to return within two weeks of their results becoming available. Patients, therefore, return anytime within 28 days of their CD4 blood draw date. Once an individual becomes eligible for ART through either WHO stage or low CD4 cell count, they are given two weeks to begin treatment. Before an individual can begin treatment, they are required to attend an ART education session with a guardian of their choice, typically a family member or friend to whom they have disclosed their status. Clinical procedures are identical at MPC and LH. Pregnant women were excluded from our study because only eligible pregnant women are referred from antenatal clinic and special procedures exist to speed ART initiation. 22

sec.title: Independent variables and covariate definitions
sec.p: Among those who initiated ART, our outcome variable of starting ART on time was defined as beginning treatment within two weeks for individuals eligible for ART through a WHO clinical staging of 3 or 4, or starting ART within 28 days from the blood draw date for patients who start because of CD4 cell count. For individuals who are determined to be ART eligible through a blood draw, starting treatment within 28 days represents the amount of time needed to process a blood sample plus the two week time period given for patients to pick up their results. All other individuals who started after their recommended time period, but within the study period, were considered to have not started treatment on time. This definition of starting ART on time reflects clinical scheduling procedures of LH and MPC.

Google Earth software was used to determine the Euclidean distance in kilometers between clinic and patient locations for LH and MPC. 23 Location information came from patients who provided either a village or area name at registration. Villages are smaller and provide more precise location information; areas are census enumeration units used for political purposes. Digital maps, from the National Statistical Office, 24 of area boundaries were layered over high resolution satellite images of Lilongwe. Members of the LH field tracing team helped identify patient villages on the digital map using area boundaries, landmarks and major intersections. When possible, the geographic centre (centroid) of a village was used for more precision. If the village centroid was unavailable, the area centroid was used as patient location. To reduce the mapping workload, only locations with 10 or more individuals were mapped. Of 152 named locations with at least 10 patients, 136 were successfully mapped (89.2%), representing 68.8% of all patients. Although more precise geographic information systems (GIS) software is available, using free Google Earth software meant that advanced computer skills and expensive software were unnecessary, making it possible for LH and MPC research staff to create this variable within existing constraints.

ART eligibility criteria were categorized as WHO stage of 3 or 4, or WHO stage of 1 or 2 combined with CD4 cell count less than 250 cells/mm3. An individual's occupation was self-reported and classified as either working in business, manual labour, professional work, not working or other. Age was classified into 10 year categories. Year of enrolment was categorized in calendar years from 2006 to 2010. An individual was classified as being underweight if their body mass index (BMI) was categorized as being less than 18.5. CD4 cell count was a continuous variable. CD4 cell count is described in our tables, but not used in our models because of its correlation with the outcome variable.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: Chi-square and Student's t-tests were used to determine significance of individual variables; alpha was set to 0.05. Logistic regression models assessed factors associated with starting ART within a recommended time period while adjusting for age, sex, BMI, ART eligibility criteria, occupation and distance to ART clinic. Additional models were stratified by distance to HIV clinic, using 10 km as a reasonable walking and biking distance in comparison with those who likely use other transportation as demonstrated by previous studies. 12,13 Analysis was conducted using SAS software (SAS institute, Cary, NC, USA).

sec.title: RESULTS
sec.p:
Out of 22,860 patients at MPC and LH, 17,851 initiated ART between 17 March 2006 and 14 August 2010. Of those, 15,734 individuals provided information on their area or village of residence. Study population density maps by area aid interpretation (Figure 1). The final study population with complete data on key variables of interest included 8178 individuals from LH and 7556 individuals from MPC (Figure 2). Of the combined clinic patients, 10,810 (68.7%) individuals began ART on time and 4924 (31.3%) individuals started ART at a later date (Figure 2). Of all clients, 73.1% were eligible to begin ART at their initial visit, and 26.9% became eligible during follow-up.

From our study population of 15,734, 76.5% initiated ART based on WHO staging while 23.5% initiated ART based on CD4 cell count. The median age of starting ART was 34 years (interquartile range [IQR] 28.3–40.7), median CD4 was 215 cells/mm3 (IQR 113–354) and most individuals were at WHO stage 3 (65.6%). Among LH patients, the median distance to clinic was 5.6 km (IQR 3.9–11.4); among MPC patients, the median distance to clinic was 4.8 km (IQR 3.8–12.3) (Table 1). The median time between ART eligibility and initiating ART was 14 days among both LH and MPC patients who started ART on time. For individuals who delayed ART initiation, the median time between ART eligibility and initiating ART was 64 days at LH and 57 days at MPC (Table 2). Univariate analysis indicated that patients who were eligible for ART based on WHO stage 1 or 2 combined with a CD4 cell count <250 cell/mm3 were less likely to begin ART on time than individuals who were eligible for ART based on a WHO stage of 3 or 4. Lower BMI, all occupations compared with not working, older age, and female gender were significantly associated with failing to start ART on time (Table 2).

Multivariable models stratified by clinic and distance to clinic are presented in Tables 3 and 4. Among LH patients, a BMI of 18.5 or less (OR 0.78; 95% CI 0.42–0.96) was associated with a lower odds of starting ART on time. Age over 40 (OR 0.53; 95% CI 0.36–0.76) and every 1 km further from LH (OR 0.97; 95% CI 0.94–0.99) decreased the likelihood of timely ART commencement. Individuals eligible for ART based on WHO stage 1 or 2 combined with a CD4 count <250 cells/mm3 versus WHO stage 3 or 4 were less likely to start treatment on time (OR 0.16; 95% CI 0.13–0.19). Business as an occupation versus unemployment increased the odds of on-time start (OR 1.90; 95% CI 1.19–3.05) (Table 3). Models stratified by distance to clinic (Table 4) show individuals with a BMI of 18.5 or less were slightly less likely to start ART on time if they lived within 10 km (OR 0.49; 95% CI 0.34–0.72) compared with individuals who lived further than 10 km from LH. Manual labourers living further than 10 km (OR 1.87; 95% CI 1.41–2.47) were also significantly more likely to start ART on time compared with manual labourers living within 10 km of LH (OR 1.39; 95% CI 0.92–2.10) (Table 4). ART eligibility at first versus subsequent clinic visit was not associated with starting ART on time.

At MPC, patients eligible for ART based on WHO stage 1 or 2 combined with a CD4 cell counts <250 cells/mm3 versus WHO staging of 3 or 4 were less likely to start ART on time (OR 0.24; 95% CI 0.21–0.28). The odds of timely ART start for patients with a BMI of 18.5 or less was lower than those with higher BMI (OR 0.69; 95% CI 0.59–0.78). Individuals aged over 40 years were less likely to begin ART on time compared with younger patients (OR 0.72; 95% CI 0.54–0.95) (Table 3). Models stratified by distance and clinic (Table 4) indicate that older persons living within 10 km of MPC were significantly more likely to start ART on time compared with younger patients within the same distance category (>20 to 30: OR 1.74; 95% CI 1.24–2.45; >30 to 40: OR 1.87; 95% CI 1.46–2.40: >40 to 50; OR 1.49; 95% CI 1.17–1.90). Individuals with a BMI of less than 18.5 living further than 10 km from MPC were less likely to start ART on time (OR 0.54; 95% CI 0.42–0.70) compared with individuals with a BMI less than 18.5 living within 10 km of MPC (OR 0.64; 95% CI 0.56–0.73) (Table 4).

sec.title: DISCUSSION
sec.p: Almost a third of our cohort (31.3%) failed to begin ART within the recommended time period, similar to cohorts from other African studies 25,26 Among individual factors, a BMI of 18.5 or less and ART eligibility criteria were associated with decreased likelihood of starting ART on time in both clinics. In contrast, being employed increased the likelihood of starting ART on time at both clinics. At LH clinic, increasing distance from HIV clinic was associated with a decreased likelihood of starting ART on time. Models stratified by distance from clinic suggest that influential factors differ: associations between starting ART on time and age, BMI, how an individual became eligible for ART, and employment varied by distance to clinic.

Distance to HIV clinic significantly associated with starting ART on time, complementing other studies which found distance to HIV clinic to be a significant factor affecting HIV care. 27,28 Our study found a 3% reduction in the odds of starting ART on time for every kilometre further from LH. In contrast, there was a positive non-significant increase associated with distance and starting ART on time at MPC indicating that distance to HIV clinic may affect individuals enrolled in LH and MPC differently. MPC is located next to Lilongwe's major bus terminal while LH is further from the transportation hubs, requiring several bus transfers for most individuals. MPC's central location and proximity to a transportation centre appears to make accessing ART easier, while those at LH may find distance and cost of transportation a barrier to care. Descriptive statistics show the average distance to LH is 16.0 km while the average distance to MPC is 12.7 km, supporting this possible explanation.

Our data indicate that employed individuals are significantly more likely to begin treatment on time compared with non-employed individuals attending either LH or MPC. For individuals living further than 10 km away from LH, all forms of employment significantly increased the likelihood of beginning ART treatment on time compared with unemployed individuals. Similar to other studies, this suggests that occupation might be an indication of the ability to pay for transport to care. In South Africa, those enrolled in ART versus those not enrolled are more likely to earn an income from formal or informal employment. 29 In Malawi, fluctuations in transportation costs have been shown to negatively affect ART use in farmers in the Thyolo district compared with individuals with higher paying, non-farming jobs. 14

As other studies have shown, it is likely that distance to HIV clinic is a proxy for distance to the closest public transportation hub. 27,30 Several variables affecting starting ART on time differ by patient location being greater than or less than 10 km from either LH or MPC. Once an individual is further than 10 km from their HIV clinic, distance to the nearest public transportation centre might be a more accurate measure of how distance affects our outcome. Potentially, once the HIV clinic exceeds walking distance, additional distance to clinic does not affect an individual's starting ART within a recommended time period.

Our data suggest that patient health and wellness plays a role in starting ART. Our study suggests that individuals who became eligible for ART due to a WHO stage 1 or 2 combined with a CD4 cell count less than 250 were less likely to start ART on time compared with individuals who became eligible for treatment with WHO stage 3 or 4. HIV-positive individuals may need to be sick enough to perceive the need for treatment, yet remain healthy enough to access care. 31,32 The significance of BMI also affirms that patient health plays a role. In all models, BMI of 18.5 or less was associated with a decreased likelihood of starting ART on time, suggesting better health increases the likelihood of starting ART on time. Moreover, employment of all types was shown to increase the likelihood of starting ART on time at LH, suggesting that ability to work meant one was healthy enough to seek HIV care.

Study patients who did not start treatment on time delayed ART initiation on average of 64 days (about two months) of becoming eligible. Delays in initiating ART have been associated with increased risk of AIDS-associated opportunistic infections and increased risk in mortality, 1,2 Previous research suggests several reasons for why patients delay ART including the fear of ART side-effects, depression and perceived HIV-associated stigma 33 as well as physical barriers such as increased distance to treatment centre and movement between areas. 34 Our study adds to the research on factors that influence initiation of ART within a recommended time period by showing increased age, unemployment and advanced WHO stage were associated with a decreased likelihood of beginning ART on time. In our study, the delay in initiation of ART also mirrors clinic procedures for routine administration of a two-month supply of co-trimoxazole (CPT) for pre ART patients, suggesting some clients may prefer to return for a routine visit rather than return only for lab results. By addressing the factors associated with delayed ART initiation, including consideration of revised CPT dispensation visit scheduling, gaps between ART eligibility and ART initiation could be reduced resulting in better clinical outcomes for patients.

It is possible unmeasured confounders affect our study's association between age and starting ART on time. Our models in Tables 3 and 4 suggest that individuals at LH and MPC who are older than 40 are less likely to start ART on time after adjusting for other factors, and this association between age and on-time start differs by distance from clinic. Socioeconomic barriers to ART initiation not captured by our study, such as education and marital status, might vary by age and could explain the association between age and starting ART on time in our study. 35

Our study has several limitations. Missing or incomplete data precluded the inclusion of all eligible patients, reducing the sample size. These persons could be dissimilar from the study population causing bias. Determining area or village distance to their HIV clinic presented several challenges. Some villages were not locatable, likely due to challenges in consistent spelling of complicated names or data entry errors in the free text box in the database. Due to the large number of villages with only one individual accessing a LH, and the effort required to map them, it was only feasible to map locations with 10 or more individuals. Furthermore, the centroid of a village or area may be quite distant from some true household locations. Despite our best efforts, 31.2% of patients who met our study criteria in other ways were excluded because they either could not be mapped or came from a village with less than 10 individuals receiving care at our two clinics. Lastly, this paper only considered patients who eventually started ART. However, further analysis of factors that influence whether an eligible patient starts ART and on the effect of on-time ART initiation on patient outcomes are required to more completely understand barriers to timely ART initiation. Although these potential biases cannot be assessed in the current study, we believe that the contributions of this study towards greater understanding of the barriers to starting ART care on time outweigh the limitations.

sec.title: CONCLUSION
sec.p: Getting patients onto ART on time continues to be a challenge in Malawi and in our clinics. Despite efforts to identify and move eligible patients into care, approximately one-third of patients failed to begin ART within a recommended time period. Overall, it appears that distance to clinic, as well as how an individual became eligible for ART, lower BMI and older age, significantly influence the odds of starting ART on time. To address these findings, further ART service decentralization efforts or more integrated services, including point of care CD4 assessments for eligibility, may help increase access for persons who live far from HIV clinics. Programmatic changes that focus on identifying persons as risk of delayed start due to BMI, WHO stage and older age, may also help get people into care earlier.
